title: El-Ganzouri Risk Index (EGRI) for Difficult Airway
description: Predicts risk of difficult airway using seven clinical parameters to guide anesthesia management and intubation strategy planning.

parameters.name: thyromental_distance
parameters.description: Thyromental distance (distance from thyroid notch to tip of mandible with neck extended)

parameters.name: mallampati_class
parameters.description: Modified Mallampati Classification (visualization of pharyngeal structures)

parameters.name: ability_to_prognath
parameters.description: Ability to advance lower jaw (prognathism) beyond upper teeth

result.name: egri_score
result.description: El-Ganzouri Risk Index score for difficult airway prediction (range: 0-12 points)

ranges.interpretation: Low risk of difficult airway. Conventional laryngoscopy and standard intubation techniques are likely to be successful. Routine airway management protocol can be followed with standard preparation and equipment readily available.

High risk of difficult airway (93.8% specificity). Consider precautions such as video-assisted laryngoscopy, awake intubation, or fiberoptic intubation. Ensure experienced anesthesiologist, difficult airway equipment available, and backup plans prepared. Consider regional anesthesia if appropriate for the procedure.

references: El-Ganzouri AR, McCarthy RJ, Tuman KJ, Tanck EN, Ivankovich AD. Preoperative airway assessment: predictive value of a multivariate risk index. Anesth Analg. 1996;82(6):1197-204. doi: 10.1097/00000539-199606000-00017.

Cortellazzi P, Caldiroli D, Byrne A, Sommariva A, Orena EF, Tramacere I. Defining and developing expertise in tracheal intubation using a GlideScope for anaesthetists with expertise in Macintosh direct laryngoscopy: an in-vivo longitudinal study. Anaesthesia. 2015;70(3):290-5. doi: 10.1111/anae.12878.

Caldiroli D, Cortellazzi P. A new difficult airway management algorithm based upon the El Ganzouri Risk Index and GlideScope® videolaryngoscope. A new look for intubation? Minerva Anestesiol. 2011;77(6):637-45.

formula: EGRI Score = mouth_opening_points + thyromental_distance_points + mallampati_points + neck_movement_points + prognath_points + weight_points + history_points. Score ≥4 indicates high risk of difficult airway.
notes: The El-Ganzouri Risk Index (EGRI) is also known as the Simplified Airway Risk Index (SARI).
Score ≥4 has 93.8% specificity for predicting difficult airway.
The index evaluates seven anatomical and historical factors associated with difficult intubation.
Mouth opening <4 cm significantly increases difficulty of laryngoscopy and intubation.
Thyromental distance <6 cm is associated with anterior laryngeal position and difficult visualization.
Modified Mallampati Class III-IV indicates limited pharyngeal space and tongue obstruction.
Reduced neck extension (<80°) limits optimal positioning for intubation.
Inability to prognath (advance lower jaw) suggests limited mandibular mobility.
Higher body weight (>110 kg) is associated with increased soft tissue mass and airway difficulty.
Previous difficult intubation history is a strong predictor of future difficulty.
The score helps guide selection of intubation technique: conventional, video laryngoscopy, or awake intubation.
High-risk patients (score ≥4) should have experienced anesthesiologist and difficult airway equipment available.
The tool is particularly useful in preoperative assessment and anesthesia planning.
Consider awake fiberoptic intubation for scores ≥7 in some practice guidelines.
Video laryngoscopy may be preferred for intermediate scores (4-6) in many centers.
The index should be used in conjunction with clinical judgment and institutional protocols.
Regional or local anesthesia may be considered as alternatives in high-risk patients when appropriate.
The score has been validated in various patient populations including head and neck cancer patients.
